text:
HAZEL SIVE: After the
genetics plus crosses segment

of this class, you
should be able to think

about a monohybrid cross
and know what that means.

You should be able to
work a Punnett square

and look how gametes segregate,
how alleles segregate,
and what the F1 looks like.

You should be able
to do an F1 cross.

You should understand
the difference
between phenotype and genotype.

You should understand
dominant and recessive

as two characteristics
of traits.

And you should understand
the notion of a test cross.

The kind of genetics that
we've been talking about

is very important
using the tools
that we've been talking about.

But sometimes, the genetics
of a particular trait
are very complicated.

There might be many
genes involved.

There might be traits that
are associated with sex.

There might be traits that are
influenced in ways that we just
don't understand.

And then we turn to
another set of tools

to understand these
complicated traits.
And those are called pedigrees.

Geneticists and doctors
understand the likelihood

that you'll come down with a
particular disorder, perhaps

Alzheimer's or some
kind of cancer.

They can help understand things
like coat color or disease

in dogs as well, which are
complicated just as in humans.

And we're going to spend
a bit of time now talking

about pedigrees and how one uses
them to understand something

about the genetics of
a particular trait.

And the way we can
define pedigrees

is that this is genetics
from a family history.

And because it's from
a family history,

we have to be able to write down
notations of what the family
history looks like.

When you write a pedigree,
there are certain designations
that you should know.

A circle refers to a
female, a square to a male.

And if either the circle
or the square is filled in,

it refers to the trait that
you're looking at is present.
It might be disease.
It might be some other trait.

You can define it, but
the trait is present.

For example, you
might have a mating
between a male and a female.

The line indicates
that there's a mating.

And the offspring--
showing you female here--

might have the particular trait
that you're interested in.

In this case, we can
actually say something

about the genetics
of this trait.
This is an affected child--
they have the trait--

that's born to two
unaffected parents.

And this is always a hallmark
of a recessive trait.

An affected child or
an affected offspring
born to two unaffected--

we'll write it out long
because it's the first time--
born to two unaffected parents.

And this would be
a characteristic
of a recessive trait.

We can do another
example where we

can see what a dominant trait
would look like in a pedigree.

For example, we might have
an affected parent mating
with an unaffected parent.

And the offspring
would be affected.

And we could further say
that that offspring then

mates with someone
who is not affected.
And they have an offspring.
And that offspring is affected.

That kind of pattern where
every affected offspring has

an affected parent
is characteristic of
a dominant trait in a pedigree.

So in this case, every
affected offspring
has an affected parent.

You have to look carefully
how I've worded it.

It's not that every
offspring will be affected.

It's that every offspring
that is affected
has an affected parent.

And every affected offspring
having an affected parent

is characteristic of a
dominant trait in the pedigree.

Let's look at a couple
of slides that will--

let's finish off that
board so that they
look nice and uniform.

And then let us look
at a couple of slides.

Here on this slide
is some nomenclature
to show you what we have--

affected females, unaffected
females, and so on,

and the bars showing
matings and offsprings.

Pedigrees for three
generations are

indicated by Roman
numerals I, II, and III

and so on the right hand
side of the pedigree.

So you can pull out the
particular generation.

Before we look at some
more examples of pedigrees,

go back and put together
a bunch of information.

And the information we
need to put together

has to do with chromosomes and
different types of chromosomes

and how different
pedigrees can be

interpreted based on these
different types of chromosomes.

There are two types of
chromosomes in most organisms.

There are autosomes, which
are the kind of chromosome
we've been talking about.

They're the ones that have
got an exactly matching pair.

They might have
different alleles

as we've explored today, but
they've got a matching pair.

There's two chromosome 1s, two
chromosome 2s, two chromosome

So the autosomes are
the paired chromosomes,

and then there are
the sex chromosomes.

I'll abbreviate chromosomes
as I did before, chr.

And these sex chromosomes
are a bit complicated.

In mammals, if you are XX
and where X is one of the sex
chromosomes, you are female.
If you're XY, you're male.

And there are all sorts
of variations of this.

But today these are
our designations.

In the XX case in a
female, this is just

like another pair
of chromosomes.

And it's kind of equivalent
to the case in autosomes.

In the case of males, these
chromosomes are unpaired.

The X and the Y
chromosomes are really
different from one another.

And that has a bunch of
implication for the traits

that come out of people who
have got particular variance
on the X chromosome.
I'm going to list a bit more.

We'll come back to the
implications in a moment.

For our purposes
in this discussion,

I'm going to distinguish three
main types of pedigree that

are based on the autosomes
or the sex chromosomes.

There is autosomal recessive,
autosomal dominant.

And these are kind of examples
we talked about above.

And these affect males
and females equally.

But then there are
X-linked recessive traits.

And in these, males
are affected more.

And they're affected
more because there's

no other allele, there's no
other X, to protect them.

And if you have a particularly
bad allele that causes disease,

let's say, on your X
chromosome, and you're a male,

that trait is going
to show itself.

It will not have
another X that might

have a different allele
that could somehow
modulate the bad allele.

And so you're going to
see a trait in males
more than in females.

And you know it's
X-linked recessive

because this trait on the X is
always transmitted to the sons
from the mother.

And that is a diagnostic for
an X-linked recessive trait.
This is a bunch of words.

So I'm going to go
now to some slides

that I've put
together for you that

will show the pedigrees
and the interpretations

for these three
different examples.

Let's start with a pedigree for
an autosomal dominant trait.

And the clue is that
every affected offspring
has one affected parent.

And the autosomal
part will give us

the indication because both
sexes will be equally affected.
So here's a pedigree.

And you might get
a problem where
you're given this pedigree.

You will get a problem where
you're given this pedigree
or something like it.

And you have to figure out is
it autosomal dominant, autosomal
recessive, X-linked recessive.

And there's some
other variations

that we won't talk about
here in this course.
So that is our challenge.

Given a pedigree, how
do we figure it out?
So you know the designations.

You know the female
is the circle.
The male is the square.

And you know filled in means
they have a particular trait.
So let us look at this.

And a clue that it
might be autosomal

is that we see both males
and females affected.

And it's not exactly
the same numbers.

But that's because
things are not always

going to be exactly
equal as expected.

Has to do with which
gametes are used and so on.

And then we can say
every affected offspring
has one affected parent.
Is that true?
And it is true.

You can see if you look at
the black filled-in parents

and the black
filled-in offspring,

they always can be traced
back to a parent that is
filled in that has the traits.

We can do better,
though, because we

can start putting in
theoretical genotypes

and asking how this
works on this pedigree.

So let us, having
thought that this

might be an autosomal
dominant trait,

let us now say, OK, that
parent, if it's dominant,

remember, if you have the
dominant allele of the gene,
you're going to have the trait.

So the parent who
doesn't have the trait
is going to be recessive.

And I've designated the
alleles little d, little d.

And the other parent
could be big D, big D,
or big D, little d.
And we can in the corner--

and you can do this while
you're doing your problems.

You can go, and you can
do the Punnett square

for this kind of
theoretical cross.

We're trying to fit the
cross to the pedigree.

And you can look at the ratio
of affected to unaffected
individuals that would come out.

And you could see that
half of the offspring

of the cross between little
d, little d, and big D,
little D would be affected.
And so that's interesting.

And if you look
at your pedigree,

you can say, ah, well,
that's interesting

because it looks like
about half of the offspring
are affected more or less.

And we can get rid of the
notion that the affected parent

in this case would be big D,
big D. Because in that case,

all of the offspring would
have the big D dominant allele.
And they all would be affected.

And you can see that in the
generation II here, which

is really the F1 generation, not
all the offspring are affected.

These are affected, and
these are not affected.

So that gives us a
sense of the genotype

and the type of inheritance
from this pedigree.

And the last thing that I'll say
about this particular example

is that you don't
always get ratios

of affected to
unaffected offspring

exactly as you would
predict because there's

some randomness in which
gametes are going to be
used in the mating process.

Example two-- and this is an
autosomal recessive trait.

But if you got this in a
problem, you wouldn't know.

We would just give
you the problem.

And you would have to figure
out is it autosomal recessive
or not.
So let's take a look at it.

Recessive traits usually
show less frequently
than dominant traits.

And you can see there's not
that many affected offspring
in this pedigree.

So that might plant
the seed that this
might be a recessive trait.

You can see that there are both
males and females affected.

So that's another clue that
this might be autosomal.

And you can see that
there are affected

offspring that are arising
from two unaffected parents.

And so that gives
you a good clue

that this is an autosomal
dominant trait--

excuse me-- an autosomal
recessive trait.

We can do what we did before and
just throw out some genotypes
and see if they work.

So let's designate that parent
as a heterozygote big R,

little r, and the other parents
as big R, little r or big R,

big R. The gametes from the
cross of the big R, little r

cross big R, little r
would look as follows.

And you'd have one, two,
three affected individuals.

And if you look
at the offspring,

there are two affected
offspring and four--

and let's see-- two affected
and two unaffected offspring.

You can see I'm hesitating
there because you

have to make sure
that you are looking

at the vertical
lines which give you

the offspring from
the parents and don't

get confused with the horizontal
lines, which refer to matings.
So OK, that sounds reasonable.

We can get rid of the big R,
big R genotype possibility.

Because if one of the parents
did have two dominant alleles,
no offspring would be affected.

And so it seems most likely
that the genotypes here

would be that both parents had
one dominant allele and one

recessive allele of a particular
gene or of a particular trait.

And then finally, let's
look at the pedigree
for an X-linked recessive trait.

Now, when you look
at this pedigree,

the first thing
you notice is that

the only affected
individuals are male.
They're the squares.

So that should start
something thinking,

ah, this has one characteristic
of X-linked recessive.

When we write these
X-linked recessive traits,

we actually write X
for the chromosome.

And we write the allele as
a kind of a superscript.

And so we're going
to make the mom--

we're going to make
the dad X superscript R
and Y. Males are XY.

And we know that if it
was a recessive trait,
the dad must have the genotype.

I've written, otherwise,
he would have the trait.

The mom could either be X
little r, little r, X big R,
X little r.

Or actually, she could
be X little r, little r.

But in that case, she
would have the trait.

And so we can get
rid of that notion.

And so what I've done is
to draw the Punnett square

for the parents where the dad
just has the big R allele that
would not give the trait.

And the mom has one big
R, one little R allele.

And you can see
again what I come up
with from the Punnett square--

and this is a bit
more complicated now

because the gametes
can be either X or Y--

is that there is one to one
affected to unaffected males.

And in this family, in
certainly the first generation,

you can't really tell
that because it's only--

there are not enough
offspring to do so.
And so that's often the case.

With pedigrees, you have to
look for several generations

to get enough offspring to get
some kind of good statistics

so that you can draw
the conclusions.

And that's why you're often
given several generations.

But you can see that following
through several generations,

there are male offspring
that are affected that are
coming from unaffected parents.

And so we got rid of
the little r, little r.

And that gives us
our three types

of pedigree characteristics
that I wanted to go over here.

As I say, there are a
couple of others that you'll
get in the more full course.
But this is enough for now.

So I want you to take
that information.

And go and do
assignment 4 for today
that has to do with pedigrees.

And go and practice figuring
out which of the pedigrees
you're seeing.
